comments.commentBody: This is a demonstration of the fact that in the vast wasteland of television, the principal of appealing to the lowest common denominator, at the lowest possible cost, is where the tv  executive earns a reputation as a mastermind. This doctrine originated with a show called "It pays to be ignorant", ( before any of you whippersnappers can remember)The ideas generated on this show  generated a class of expensively tailored, silver tongued slicksters, whose suctorial powers to their bosses would have generated envy in engineers designing cooling apparatus for nuclear power plants.
Throve?
I had forgotten that " It pays to be ignorant" was a radio show whose basic premise was quickly snapped up by TV.
Anyone remember new Coke?

Design and layout of this app is great! The cowbell is awesome but love the twitter feed. Now I can follow all these guys but don't have to clog up my twitter account! Can't wait to start watching the USA medals build in the medal count section!
Creative genius!  Hope to see everyone ringing their "cowbell" on the slopes!
Awesome app - download it now!
This app is awesome! Go Team USA!

Such an awesome app! The cowbell really does sound authentic too - I was surprised with how loud it can really get! But the medal count and schedule really just makes this a great app. Can't wait for the games to start...

Seems more than a bit silly to find a few seconds of torch relay film from the 1936 Olympics offensive while not, apparently, being troubled by the entire idea of a torch relay --  something that was invented to publicize those same Berlin games.

I LOVE the food in Vancouver and I've eaten all over the world. The sushi is the best anywhere- my fave place is  Yuji's Japanese Tapas on 4th Ave. The fish is so fresh, the menu divine, great prices and charming staff. For pastries, Thomas Haas on Broadway is simply amazing- the double baked almond croissant is a dream come true.

I'm not sure I agree with arthur 118. I found the clues to be a delightful mare's nest of misdirection. Yes, the puzzle is doable, but for me there was a lot of head scratching between 22A, my first get, and 2D, which I've never heard of but which, thanks to ARETE, finished the puzzle. As to things I've never heard of, add 3D, 7D, those two MIROS, and 23A.

I've always thought of MADD as a vociferous and righteous advocacy organization, not a safety organization, though its activities have certainly improved road safety. Am I just being curmudgeonly because I was stuck on OSHA?

As usual, Bob, you are the one editorial writer with a finger on the pulse of that which is truly important to the working citizen.  One of Obama's biggest problems is that he has no businessmen in the circle of his advisors.  He has plenty of bankers and finance people, but not people who have done things to create jobs.  His first target should be across-the- board tax cuts for anyone who is not in the top one percent of earners in the country.  His next target should be the removal of as many rules, regulations, and other restrictions, as possible, from small businesses.  With these two steps he could invigorate the economy in a way not seen since the times of Ronald Reagan.

The acts of stopping or blocking are as much affirmative actions as the act of allowing.  A vote of no is still a vote.  Much of what both houses of congress do is , in fact, bad for the average citizen.  Rather than complain about the obstructionists, we should vote in more of them

"And it will require leadership that pulls together the best talents from all sectors of the society — not just business, not just government, but from everywhere."

You are correct, because when we as Americans work together, not as red-blue adversaries, but as red-white-and-blue partners in helping our nation advance, we all live happier lives and our kids will inherit it in at least the same condition.

This idea reminds me of how ancient Asian rulers are ranked. The worst are tyrants who tax people as much as possible. The good ones are those who help the people become prosperous. However, the best are such that when you ask any random person who is your ruler, he or she would say, "We have a ruler?" Therefore, no one leader will make our lives better; we must do it ourselves, together!

Thomas Huynh, founder
Sonshi

President Obama turned the corner that fateful Friday in his meeting with the GOP. If he wants to turbo charge his approval from the American people, however, he must dress down the Democrats in similar fashion as well. As President, he must understand he is no longer a leader of Democrats but now a leader of all Americans.

Thomas Huynh, founder
Sonshi

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Are you writing of the Keystone Cops or the U.S. Senate?

Back in ancient Athens, when they started up this democracy thing, all office holders got there by lottery. That wss fair. Representative. So it makes us all prouder that Americans, in affirmative action service to the 50% with IQs below 100, have improved on the ancient Greeks to make sure so largely the dumbest, dimmest, doofiest get their six years or more in this U.S. Senate.

No need to represent all the people -- no need, as you point out, too, ever to get anything done. They got their health, dental, & vision needs all fully comped. Pensions building. Lots of lobbyists lining them up so they never need to go "home" after their initial six years or more in service to the corporate interests.

And for lame-brain glories to perform in D.C. -- what a place. The wars can just go on and on, the schools go down and down the tubes, and . . . well, never mind the list of what Americans are doing. This Senate they've got reminds us all that Americans don't particularly need to do anything, or make any efforts. The corporate interests will take care of everything -- and these senators can complete the comedy.

My "gimme's" were the internet, where I had to look up the Browning quote, and the location of the Bruce peninsula--I got impatient.  Usually if I hang in I can get even the Friday and Saturday puzzles on my own.   For Summit success, I kept thinking mountain climbing--that was the last one I filled in.   Slowed myself down by guessing "real men" instead of "good men" and I also tried "runs at" instead of "goes at".  I also initially input "rial" iinstead of "riel".  And I kept visualizing a tipped sidewalk--not sure when I figured out it was street musicians.  Fun puzzle, not too bad for a Friday.

If your are looking for the best food in Vermont, then look no further than Santos Cocina Latina in Stowe, Vermont. It is chef owned and operated which we find always make a huge difference. To be quite honest the Latin American food is better than we we have in NYC. You will savor every bite, and scrape your fork across the plate. Seriously Santos where have you been all my life? Anazing food,service, art= six stars.

Bravo

As a physical therapy student with a specific interest in shoulder rehab, I was speaking with an acquaintance who was explaining his shoulder injury. Rather than stating he had a "labral tear" (of the glenoid labrum, in the shoulder joint), he said - while holding his shoulder - he had a "labial tear." It was difficult to gently correct his terminology, explain the difference, and express my sympathy with a straight face, but I do hope his labia has healed well by now.
I'm going to win Schott's competition if it kills me.
Rosebud.
Here is the tunnel at the end of the light.
My aim is this, to sail beyond the sunset and all the baths of the western world!

Because I was an overachiever,
Now I am an under achiever.
